body: Done.
@drcrallen Fwiw, I'm not sure which CLA you are believing that Bingkun has filled out, but he was added a while back to our corporate CLA.
Actually, no, he's apparently not covered yet.  Need to correct that.
@cheddar @guobingkun filled out the individual CLA. He wasn't covered on the corporate CLA and we can't always tell which company someone is from :)
@drcrallen thanks for the clarification, i did changed the description.

Thanks for the hints. I've tried both options (and also a combination of both). Delivery confirmation seems to improve the situation a bit, but it still happens, although kinda less often.
Still looking for a reliable solution :-).

On a side question (but maybe related). Do you know why elements sometimes do not appear in "basePersistDirectory"? They are shown in logs in processed and I can query for them, but they're not in the dir. And apparently they are also still sitting in rabbit. Could it be some problem with rabbit firehose? [Dunno if this is true in 0.7, spotted in 0.6 only so far.]

when events are ingested they are added to an in memory buffer first, 
these events are then persisted to disk i.e basePersistDirectory either periodically (configured by intermediatePersistPeriod) or hitting a threshold on number of rows in memory (configured via rowFlushBoundary), its fine to not see events getting written to disk as soon as they are getting ingested but they are made queryable from in memory buffer.
@xvrl  Added simple serde tests

Given that we don't really have a good fix for this issue yet, I am going to close this PR until we have a better solution. @b-slim do you mind filing a corresponding issue so we don't forget about this?

That makes sense, must have been sleepy yesterday. And copies are probably left in the queue to prevent data loss in case node fails to flush to disk for some reason. Yeah, makes sense, thanks for the explanation. So the OT section is closed for now :-).
LGTM, do you mind [signing our CLA](http://druid.io/community/cla.html) so you we can merge this?
@cheddar Can you add me to the corporate CLA if I'm not already there?
@xvrl we already have the corporate CLA
@rasahner my bad, didn't realize you were on that, it's hard to keep track of all nicknames :)

@xvrl  had suggested moving some of the prioritized stuff out of the MetricsEmittingExecutorService. I refactored things a bit so that wrappers are present in the MetricsEmittingExecutorService and PrioritizedExecutorService.
@nishantmonu51 I think xavier made a similar fix, can you update your branch to be mergable?

@nishantmonu51 I fixed that issue as well as a bunch more in order query types as part of #1304.
We can add you tests though if you want.
@fjy is this a test to define the behavior or to highlight an existing issue?
@fjy squash and I'll merge
This came about because I was having some validation issues when recompressing some older segments.

Fwiw, the integration of the geospatial indices is also quite clunk-clunk, to use the technical term.

It would be great to see about extending the types of things that columns can do to support a GeoSpatial index or figure out a way to make the geo spatial indexing fit the current set of things that columns can do a little better...

Just tested latest commit with old metrics data. Seems to be working. The following query returns results that only differ by `X-Druid-Query-Id`:

``` json
{
  "queryType"  : "topN",
  "dataSource" : "hadoop_tpch",
  "granularity": "all",
  "threshold":100,
  "dimension":"host",
  "metric":"value",
  "context":{"useCache":false,"populateCache":false,"bySegment":false, "finalize":true, "useOffheap":false},
  "intervals": [ "1900-01-09T00:00:00.000Z/2992-01-10T00:00:00.000Z" ],
  "aggregations": [
    { "type": "doubleSum",   "name": "value",            "fieldName": "value" },
    { "type": "count",       "name": "count" },
    { "type": "longSum",     "name": "total_count",      "fieldName": "count" }
  ]
}
```

Where hadoop_tpch is the datasource I hacked up to get only the metrics segment of interest in there.

Ok, I just read over all of the functional code (I skipped over some of the test code, specifically around the ExtractionManagers and stuff because I'd like discussion around that interface to settle a bit first)

The description on this pull request is not really enough to help me understand what is going on.  I read through the issue as well and nowhere is it explained what the problem was and how it is being fixed.

I'm going to now dive into the code and see if I can reverse out what the issues are, but please make it a habit to provide more information about what is wrong and how you are intending to fix it.

Ok, if I'm understanding the changes correct, it would appear that we are doing work before persisting the index as well as when querying to convert "bad" input into what the rest of the system expects.  Is it possible for us to do the conversion at ingestion time instead of persist time?  

That seems like it could be more robust and require changes in less locations.
have updated the PR description for more details on the problem and the fix

Issue was that IncrementalIndex was not able to tell whether a column contains a null 
the changes make IncrementalIndex aware of null values, i.e now the DimDim assigns an id to a null value and stores it as blank string, the logic for conversion from null to empty string and vice versa is encapsulated within NullValueConverterDimDim. at persist time what we do is skip empty columns, will check any redundant work being done while persisting and clean that up.
@cheddar which conversion during persist you are referring to that can be done at the ingestion time ?

travis failing at IndexIOTest, 
case of failure - 
Index1 - 
row1 = dim0 -> ["dim00", "dim01"]
row2 = dim1  -> ["dim10"]
row3 = **dim0** -> null

Index2 - 
row1 = dim0 -> ["dim00", "dim01"]
row2 = dim1  -> ["dim10"]
row3 = **dim1** -> null 

with the changes in the PR the generated indexes are similar both having 3 rows and does not distinguish between the facts that in first case row3 has dim0 mapped to null and dim1 absent while in second case dim0 is absent and dim1 is mapped to null. 

I think its correct to treat missing and null value same and we need to fix the test. 
@cheddar, @xvrl  what are your views on this ?

As a counter-example, if you were to issue a `topN` over dim1  using a "count" agg as the sorting metric, the results should be different in each case whereby the first case returns "dim10":1 and the second case returns "dim10":1, "null":1
I feel the correct behaviour in both the cases for topN over dim1 should return "dim10":1, "null":2

I'm happy to merge this once:
- [ ] everyone is ok with making the backwards incompatible change in metrics. @cheddar, thoughts?
- [ ] remaining issues with exceptions being thrown are resolved
LGTM , however can you please update the PR description with "why" this change was needed or the motivation behind?

@estliberitas Thanks for the contrib! Do you mind signing our CLA?

http://druid.io/community/cla.html
@fjy done ;)

@himanshug the motivation behind this is to speed up the conversion task. For old segments that fall prey to issue #1309, the added time necessary to compare values in addition to indices doubles the amount of time it takes to convert a segment.
@xvrl @drcrallen thanks for the explanation and updating the PR. It makes sense now.
@xvrl @himanshug Addressed all code review comments.
@xvrl @himanshug Any thoughts?
LGTM, @himanshug any other comments?

@infynyxx Unless we have a good reason to require anything older than 2.3, I would prefer we leave the default at the minimum version required, and add separate build profiles for different versions / flavors of hadoop, [similar to what Spark does](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/pom.xml#L1633)
@xvrl Sounds good. Closing this PR.

@davideanastasia, would it work to add some or'ed checks to the s3_zip conditional saying that we should do that if it's a S3NativeFileSystem _or_ if finalIndexZipFilePath's scheme is "s3" or "s3n"? I think that should fix your problem but also not break the behavior for null schemes.
LGTM
@gianm what you are proposing should work. Would you like me to do the change?
@davideanastasia, if you could, that would be awesome.

I have also been pushing for more and better URI support. This patch went in recently which started adding more URI standard usage in the code:

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1132
do we have to update docs as well or not?
@xvrl No, I already updated them in the metrics PR

@xvrl @cheddar @fjy any thoughts on the behaviour of null vs absent values for failing IndexIOTest ?
curious as to what usecase needs this?

Proposal for the change is discussed here - 
https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/druid-development/873eac97-c605-4e4e-8568-78c302f5468f%40googlegroups.com
@himanshug I believe this is to expand the features of the coordinator console and enables the coordinator console to only talk to to the coordinator to get everything it needs.

@nishantmonu51 :+1:

The third row should have `null` for both `dim0` and `dim1` even if it is only specifying one of them.

One way to think about those types of problems would be to map the problem back to what happens when we materialize the index. In my opinion, it makes sense for the IncrementalIndex to behave the same way that the corresponding segments converted to read-only format would. I believe that's what you are trying to do here @nishantmonu51, correct?
thanks for the info and the link. I guess, we should always put the link to proposal discussion in the issue/PR description/comments so that context is clear for anyone reading the PR or issue.

Thanks for answering, Nishant and Fangjin.

Himadri - as Fangjin said, this is in order to allow the coordinator console to access cluster endpoints (specifically the indexing overlord in this case) that are not served by the coordinator.  This will enable the coordinator console to provide a more complete view of the cluster.  Let me know if you have any questions.
@tarekrached @himanshug != Himadri :). Himanshu is a Druid developer at another organization.
doh!  my apologies to both @himanshug and our own Himadri - apparently I can only process the first 4 letters of a name :/
@tarekrached no probs, happens :)
LGTM
thanks xvrl, cheddar, have fixed the failing test

Hi @davrodpin, are you planning on adding `container` to the loadSpec in this PR?
It would be nice if we could include this as part of the next release in a form that we can support going forward.
Hey @xvrl, I'm planning to push this change that adds the `container` until the end of this week.
@davrodpin Awesome, thanks!
can we write some instructions somewhere on how to fix this, that we'll include in the release notes, so people can fix their tables when upgrading?
Is it possible to fix the test instead of removing it?

Hi @T0aD,

I don't believe this is a software problem as much as it is a setup problem. Druid's realtime ingestion is designed to block ingestion is there are too many pending persists. This is to prevent nodes from running out of memory and crashing entirely. The times seen for creating some of your dimensions are absolutely insane and completely not normal, and points to improper configuration or improper setup.

I'm going to repeat what I've mentioned a few times already. Given the tidbits of information I have seen about your cluster, I strongly believe that your cluster is misconfigured. We'd be very happy to help straighten things out, but we need more information about how you guys are setting things up.

@fqtyfz I don't know of anyone that has managed to get Druid working on Windows thus far.
All the Druid deployments we know of run on Linux.

There are probably many places in the codebase that assume the underlying OS is unix-like, so if you are just getting started with Druid, I would recommend testing things out on Linux or OS X. It should
have no issues running in a virtual machine either.
Thanks @KenjiTakahashi, I'm going to close this for now, please reopen if the issue pops up again

@bobrik Druid currently always announces itself on the port it binds to. It would require some work to make those two distinct. Druid announces itself externally, but also uses some of those mechanisms internally to talk between nodes, so it would require clarifying whether internal communication between nodes should go over the announced port or the port it binds to.

I will update the title of the issue to make it more clear what you are referring to.
@bobrik This is an issue with some of our other configuration parameters as well, such as metadata storage. If something unknown is specified it will just fall back to the default
@haadcode this should have been fixed in the latest release, please reopen if this is still an issue
#1262 should fix this

> it would require clarifying whether internal communication between nodes should go over the announced port or the port it binds to.

Announced port should be used for communication between nodes. My use-case is docker image where druid always binds to port 8080 in private net, but exposed port can be arbitrary (e.g. assigned by mesos). Nodes can only see each other on announced (exposed) port.
@xvrl is it a good strategy for some configuration parameters? I think it's better to fail fast and loud if config is invalid in any way.
@bobrik no, I agree we should fail gracefully instead of using the default.

@xvrl I've update PR description with migration steps required.

I have tested those for mysql. dint have a postgres installation so couldn't test. Can someone please validate the steps for postgres? thanks.
Test was against the 05-06 conversion, which was eliminated in the "lost commit" in favor of the 06-07 conversion. Tests probably need to be rewritten for 06-07
@himanshug had created tests between the lost commit and the re-instatement of the lost commit, which were against the old 0.6.x branch version of the class.
@himanshug can you test postgresql locally?
@janakg Just to follow up with our in person sync up, I'd be happy to merge this once the diagram is hosted on a different page
@fjy ok, I checked the steps on a locally installed postgres server and steps shown in the PR description worked just fine.
@himanshug Thanks!

@cheddar : I migrated the data off of persistent ZK nodes and into metadata

Now here is how namespace populating works:
1. The namespace serving nodes announce (through `Announcer`) that it exists
2. The Coordinator listens for this announcement and fires off a list of namespaces to the node
3. The Coordinator regularly polls the metadata and POSTs the most recent list to the namespace servicing nodes on each update round.
4. The namespace servicing nodes determine what to add or drop each time the new list is sent to them.

Since everything is loaded everywhere this approach is an "at least once announcement" kind of approach and things eventually settle onto a state as the leading coordinator keeps polling the metadata and spitting out the "correct" state to each node.

yes, i think it was testing 5to6 property conversions and not valid with changed code which does 6to7 conversion.
With #1323 we've sort-of made implicit decision that "convertProps" wouldn't support 5to6 conversions.
If we still want to support both 5to6 and 6to7 configuration updates then we can probably have classes

ConvertProperties5To6.java (command "convertProps5to6")
ConvertProperties6To7.java (command "convertProps6to7")
and this model can be extended to further version updates.

It's unlikely that someone would be able to upgrade straight from 0.5.x to 0.7.x so we decided to remove the 0.5 -> 0.6 convertprops in 0.7, and only leave them in the 0.6 branch.

@himanshug would you like to contribute tests for the 0.6 -> 0.7 conversion instead?

The upgrade convention was one that was decided upon among a relatively small group of people: That any major version must be able to upgrade properties from the prior major version, but is not required to support upgrades from older versions. If that needs to change it would be very worth bringing up to a wider discussion.
@xvrl sure, I will send updated UTs .
Closing to test real quick
Ok, seems to join fine
In that case we should also change all the other default service names, since they currently all use `druid/` as prefix. It wouldn't make senose to mix and match.
This is a dupe of #709.
@xvrl , makes sense.. I thought druid.service was not set by default. updated that too.

@xvrl yeah, I noticed that today in DruidNode code. Actually having "druid/" node as prefix is not that big of a deal. I removed it believing that was simplest and consistent to do. I don't think this is big enough to introduce backward incompatibility.
Let us just fix the documentation. how does that sound?
